#loading libraries & the dataset

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
uber_data = pd.read_csv('../input/uber-drive-dataset/uberdrive.csv')
source.d8501313:
# Showing last ten records for the dataset

uber_data.tail(10)
source.49426ede:
# showing first ten records of the dataset

uber_data.head(10)
source.efda3731:
# Checking for Missing Values in the original dataset(Outplut in boolean only)

uber_data.isna()

# True indicates there are missing values in the data
source.e7d36f67:
# Sum of those missing values in the original dataset

uber_data.isna().sum()
source.a35e615e:
# Dropping the missing values and naming the dataset as 'df'

df = uber_data.dropna()
source.33e07f70:
# Unique values in the Start column for the data with no missing values 'df'

df['START*'].unique()
source.ee1d543a:
# Sum of unique values in the Start column for the data with no missing values 'df'

df['START*'].nunique()
source.1661d577:
# Printing total number of unique stop destinations for the data with no missing values 'df'

print(df['STOP*'].nunique())
source.c7c2b875:
# Printing all the trips that is started from the point of San Francisco for the original data 'uber_data'.

print(uber_data[uber_data['START*'] == "San Francisco"])
source.4859fe40:
#Most popular starting point for the data with no missing values 'df'.

df['START*'].value_counts().nlargest(n=1)
source.08a00faf:
#Most popular dropping point for the data with no missing values 'df'

df['STOP*'].value_counts().nlargest(n=1)
source.c6fed813:
# Listing the top ten frequent routes taken by the Uber drivers for the data with no missing values 'df'

df.groupby(['START*','STOP*']).size().sort_values(ascending=False).head(1)

# Cary to Morrisville is the top most frequent route taken by the Uber drivers.
source.0a8924ad:
#Printing all types of purposes for the trip and its miles in an array for the dataset with no missing values 'df'

print(np.array(df['PURPOSE*'].dropna().unique()))
df['MILES*'].groupby(df['PURPOSE*']).sum().sort_values(ascending = False)

# Significant trips are for meetings and customer visit.
source.f2ed5278:
# Barplot for Purposes vs Distance for the original dataset "uber_data".

df1 = uber_data.groupby('PURPOSE*')['MILES*'].sum().sort_values(ascending=False).head(10) 
df1
df1= df1.reset_index() # resetting the index
df1
df1.columns = ['PURPOSE*' ,'Total_Miles']
df1
%matplotlib inline
sns.barplot(data= df1 , x= 'PURPOSE*' , y ='Total_Miles').set_title('Purpose vs Distance')
plt.xticks(rotation=90)
source.fbe00a5e:
# Printing a dataframe for the pupose of the trips and their respective total distance from the original database 'uber_data'.

purpose_dist = uber_data.groupby('PURPOSE*').sum()['MILES*'].sort_values(ascending = False)
print(purpose_dist)
source.4dc9064f:
# Plotting number of trips by category from original database 'uber_data'

ax = sns.countplot(x = uber_data['CATEGORY*'], data=uber_data, hue='CATEGORY*', palette="Set3")

# More trips are made for business pupose than the personal purpose.
source.aa041011:
# Proportion of trips between business & personal purpose for the original database 'uber_data'.

categorries_prop = uber_data.groupby('CATEGORY*').agg({'MILES*':'sum'})
categorries_prop
categorries_prop.apply(lambda x: x/x.sum()*100).rename(columns = {'MILES':'% of Miles'})

source.5b2a57cf:
## Uber Drive - Solved
Instructions:

For all questions in which the dataframe is used without dropping na, row number-1155 should be included.
For Q6 :- Output should be boolean only.
For Q9 :- Outcome will contain only numerical column.
For Q11 :- You need to print the unique destination place names in this and not the count.
For Q15,16 :- Popular: It is the place that is visited the most.
For Q17 :- Print the most frequent route taken by Uber drivers after dropping null values (Route= combination of START & END points present in the Data set). *Note: Only the top most value is expected
For Q19 :- You have to plot total/sum miles per purpose.
For Q21 :- You can make a countplot or barplot.
For Q22 :- Out of the category of trips, you need to find percentage wise how many are business and how many are personal on the basis of miles per category.
For all questions after 10th, Please only use the data specified in the note given just below the question
You need to add answers in the same file i.e. PDS_UberDriveProject_Questions.ipynb' and rename that file as 'Name_Date.ipynb'.You can mention the date on which you will be uploading/submitting the file.For e.g. if you plan to submit your assignment on 31-March, you can rename the file as 'STUDENTNAME_31-Mar-2020'
